Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Proposal: Virginia Union University Undergraduate Research Training Program in the Biological Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Virginia Union University (VUU) seeks to develop and implement course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in the biology education curriculum, provide access to scientific research experiences for undergraduate students and increase the research capacity of faculty in the biological sciences. The proposed program is a strategy for increasing the capacity of VUU to produce more STEM graduates who are competitive for graduate school and STEM careers. It is anticipated that this program will enhance the quality of STEM education at VUU, leading to the formation of a new research-intensive academic curriculum.


The goals of the project are to increase the number of competitive VUU biology graduates entering STEM graduate programs and/or workforce, as well as the faculty capacity for conducting STEM research at a small, liberal arts HBCU. These goals will be accomplished through the following specific objectives: (1) increase biology student exposure and competency in laboratory-based technological advances that are most relevant to graduate training and/or the scientific workforce; (2) increase student engagement in formal basic science training and independent research experiences; and (3) enhance faculty discipline-specific expertise and increase the capacity to conduct scientific research. A 3-pronged approach will be used to fulfill these objectives: 1) develop and implement course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in the biology education curriculum; 2) implement a set of extracurricular activities targeting key aspects of faculty and student research development needs; and 3) implement an Undergraduate Research Certificate Program in the biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Targeted Infusion Proposal: Virginia Union Universigy Undergraduate Research Training Program in the Biological Sciences involved the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based models to bolster reseach capacity at a small, liberal arts histoically black university. The goals of this project were to increase the number of competitive VUU biology graduates entering STEM graduate programs and/or workforce, as well as increase faculty capacity for conducting STEM research .

Three specific objectives were identified for this purpose:

(1) increase biology student exposure and competency in laboratory-based technological advances that are most relevant to graduate training and/or the scientific workforce;

(2) increase student engagement in formal basic science training and independent research experiences; and

(3) enhance faculty discipline-specific expertise and increase the capacity to conduct scientific research.

A 3-pronged approach was used to fulfill these objectives: 1) develop and implement course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in the biology education curriculum; 2) implement a set of extracurricular activities targeting key aspects of faculty and student research development needs; and 3) implement an Undergraduate Research Certificate Program in the biological sciences.

The project outcomes are as follows:

Intellecutual Merit: We have successfully integrated course-based research experiences (CUREs) into entry-level Biological Sciences courses and provided CUREs to a significant number of Biology majors during the project period. In addition, we established a neurophysiology research laboratory (Ruffin NeuroLab) in 2018 to advance the co-PI's (Dr. Ruffin’s) research and provide undergraduates with advanced research experiences. While we were successful in having approved through the academic review council an Undergraduate Research Cerificate program, we are investigating the extent to which this informs our understanding of undergraduate student preparation for STEM graduate education/workforce.

Broader Impacts: Overall, this project was specifically developed to increase the capacity of VUU to produce more STEM graduates who are competitive for graduate school and STEM careers. Through enhancing the quality of STEM education by implementing CUREs, we have formed new reseach-intensive academic curricula. The VUU Science Research Journal Club was established and will continue to engage faculty and students throughout all programs in the VUU Department of Natural Sciences. In addition, the department-wide Summer Undergraduate Research Program with a unified participant handbook provides a framework for research intensive experiences.
